title: Friday, 29th April, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Hi there

PM

I can't believe I missed this St Jude stuff late session yesterday, but maybe come back to that

PM

Should stick to today's most important news

11:01 am
PM

Which also provides today's pic

PM

PM

There it is

11:02 am
BE

Well ............ I guess ZH and Bloomberg do compete, in a sense.

PM

Bloomberg citing itself alongside the No1 source of financial wingnuttery

PM

We've been enjoying this piece this morning

11:02 am
PM

http://www.bloombe...et-s-renegade-blog

PM

Colin Lokey, also known as "Tyler Durden," is breaking the first rule of Fight Club: You do not talk about Fight Club. He’s also breaking the second rule of Fight Club. (See the first rule.)
After more than a year writing for the financial website Zero Hedge under the nom de doom of the cult classic’s anarchic hero, Lokey’s going public. In doing so, he’s answering a question that has bedeviled Wall Street since the site sprang up seven years ago: Just who is Tyler Durden, anyway?
The answer, it turns out, is three people. Following an acrimonious departure this month, in which two-thirds of the trio traded allegations of hypocrisy and mental instability, Lokey, 32, decided to unmask himself and his fellow Durdens.
Lokey said the other two men are Daniel Ivandjiiski, 37, the Bulgarian-born former analyst long reputed to be behind the site, and Tim Backshall, 45, a well-known credit derivatives strategist. (Bloomberg LP competes with Zero Hedge in providing financial news and information.)
In a telephone interview, Ivandjiiski confirmed that the men had been the only Tyler Durdens on the payroll since Lokey came aboard last year, but he criticized his former colleague's decision to come forward.

PM

Of course we've known that Dan Ivandjiiski ran ZH for years

11:03 am
PM

About 7 years in fact

PM

But whatever

BE

But it's certainly sensational stuff from Mr Lokey, the clickbait Snowden, that ZH is a trollfeed silo.

11:04 am
PM

It's a good Bloomberg story in any case

PM

Exactly

PM

Think the most comprehensive piece on ZH was back in the New York Mag

11:04 am
PM

http://nymag.com/g.../index1.html#print

BE

It is, we mist repeat, a good story. The amazing thing is that Mr Lokey seems to have joined with good intentions.

PM

But it's fun now that ZH people are eating each other

11:05 am
PM

We should stage something similar on AV

PM

Oh, we already did with your famous sulk Bryce

BE

Ah, yes. My famous sulk.

11:06 am
PM

Maybe this Lokey stuff is a similar stunt

PM

But look, it's quite busy

BE

It's a false flag resignation! OF COURSE!

11:06 am
BE

You've just leveled up the conspiracy! We've out ZH'd ZH!

PM

Excellent. I guess we should get on with some proper news

BE

Guess so.

11:07 am
PM

Do you have that Star headline to hand?

BE

Oh, the splash? Sure.

BE

11:08 am
BE

Sorry for the slight NSFW-ness.

PM

Editor in chief of Bloomberg in the UK tabs

PM

Leading a UK tab in fact

11:09 am
BE

Which churns a column he wrote on Tuesday.

BE

On one side of modern journalism we have tinfoil click farms. On the other we have skin-heavy tabloids splashing on four-day old columns from the former editor of the Economist.

BE

I'm not sure where we fit into all this.

11:10 am
undefined
BE

Okay! Where to begin?

PM

On that note...

11:11 am
PM

Can you run us through the main movers Bryce?

BE

Sure, we're mostly down.

BE

FTSE off 0.6% at 6285.

11:12 am
BE

And there's actual bad news around. Quite a lot of it.

BE

We can start, I guess, with the Restaurant Group profit warning.

PM

Some scorchedfingers here

11:12 am
BE

Yup. Which has caused a fair bit of scorchedfingers due to recent, very vague, speculation of PE interest.

BE

And I guess it's now 25% cheaper for PE.

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 287.24, down 87.06 (-23.26%), High: 335.00, Low: 282.10, Volume: 8.05m
11:13 am
PM

Well there's that argument

BE

The other argument, of course, is that it's now deep in crisis.

BE

Frankie & Benny's seems not to be working as a brand any more.

11:14 am
BE

1950s themed American Italian food is not the niche it was, I guess.

PM

You don't think it is across the board? This strategy of taking good single restaurants and diluted the hell out of them is bound to fail?

BE

Well, that's the other argument.

11:15 am
BE

Or one of them. The problem with scaling up and rolling out isn't necessarily that quality suffers .....

PM

You just lose the personal touch -- and end up with uncommitted staff, working for a few months on minimum wage

PM

go on

11:16 am
BE

You've done this argument before and I disagree, but don't have time to disagree at length today.

PM

ok ok

BE

What we can say is that F&B was never particularly ......... um ....... about the food. See its Instagram: https://www.instag...nkienbennys/?hl=en

11:17 am
BE

It's about a place to go before you go to the cinema.

PM

Sheesh, steady with the images

BE

And on that note, CINE:LSE

11:17 am
Cineworld Group PLC (CINE:LSE): Last: 516.50, down 25 (-4.62%), High: 537.50, Low: 516.00, Volume: 211.22k
BE

Okay, so we have the environment being tough.

BE

Coffer Peach last month was weak, but not this weak.

11:18 am
BE

LFL sales growth for the companies within the tracker was +0.6% in March, but that included Easter, which 2015 didn't.

BE

But Coffer data also showed that it was pubs that were underperforming, not restaurants.

BE

The issue with restaurants is supply, not demand. And increased supply means brands go stale quicker. And F&B is Restaurant Group's stalest brand, so it's suffering most.

11:19 am
BE

Let me grab some sellside.

BE

Canaccord.

BE

One man's profit warning, is another man's profit opportunity

11:20 am
BE

Aye ......

BE

Restaurant Group's profit
warning duly arrived this morning and we are cutting our EPS (Dil Adj) by 14.1% for
FY16E and by 12.9% for FY17E which is based on the bottom of the new PBT guidance
£74m -£80m from this morning. Frankie & Benny's is the problem brand and in need of
a major overhaul but it is not a broken brand, in our view. The launching of a strategic
review is a start but we will continue to sit on the sidelines until we see the conclusions
in August. We retain our HOLD recommendation but reduce our target price to 276p from
400p.

BE

Today's unscheduled profit warning revealed that L4L sales are -2.7% in the 17 weeks
ended 24 April, a deterioration from the -1.5% for the first eight weeks. This translates
into PBT falling to the range of £74m to £80m versus our previous £86.5m for FY16.
We would not be surprised if we saw another cut to forecasts this year. It's a highly
operationally geared model and it's very painful when trade declines. Frankie & Bennys
(c50% of the business) is struggling and we estimate that L4L sales could be in doubledigit
decline driven by (1) the market moving quicker than RTN can react to (we suspect
there are some very poor performers in its portfolio) and (2) the brand starting to
be tired. We expect the review to result in a list of identified disposals (20-30), a
major overhaul of the brand, accelerated depreciation and write-downs, and higher
maintenance capex. Management was hesitant on reconfirming the dividend policy (is it
to be maintained? or is it 2x covered?). Expansion capex needs to slow but not stop, RTN
must keep following the consumer and keep taking the best sites.

11:20 am
BE

There's been some really interesting stuff leading up to this about Restaurant Group intentionally cannibalising its own sites

BE

Just to stop competitors getting the pitches.

BE

Because the anathema to this model is choice.

11:21 am
BE

See also SSP and WH Smith, which have been better at protecting their patches.

BE

Back to Canaccord.

BE

We have assumed the dividend is cut in line with our EPS estimate, maintaining cover
at broadly 2x, which at 15.0p is 14% lower than our previous estimate. At this level,
expansionary capex and the dividend are no longer covered by free cash flow, and
management needs to consider cutting the dividend. But on the positive side, net debt is
low at just 0.3x EBITDA.

11:22 am
BE

We have now cut our forecasts three times since November, and it would not surprise us
if there were another cut to forecasts this year. Our new 276p target price is derived from
a 9.0x PE to FY17E. At this price the stock is on a free cash flow yield of 16.3% in FY17E,
and a dividend yield of 5.8%.

BE

And JP Morgan.

BE

The Restaurant Group has issued a warning that its profit before tax in
2016 is expected to be in the range £74-80 million, with LFLs of between -
2.5% and -5.0%. We have lowered our PBT estimate by 14% to £77.7
million from £90.1 million. The trading performance of the Leisure
portfolio has deteriorated further in recent weeks and is not expected to
improve materially in the short-term. We see this as an issue of
intensifying competitive pressure for which there seems no quick fix. The
group has initiated a strategic review, which could drive an improvement.
We remain Neutral with a reduced target price of 400p (Jun-17).
 LFLs impacted by worsening footfall. The Restaurant Group (TRG)
has experienced a further deterioration in trading conditions since last
talking to the market on 9 March. LFL sales in the first 17 weeks are
down -2.7% (from -1.5% in early March), implying -4.4% for the past
seven weeks. TRG does not expect any short-term improvement and has
guided to a full-year expectation for LFLs of between -2.5% and -5.0%.
This causes it to guide to PBT of between £74 million and £80 million.
It appears that footfall across TRG’s leisure estate has been
disappointing, with its largest brand Frankie & Benny’s putting most of
the pressure on the group’s performance.
 PBT estimate reduced by 14% in 2016. Directionally, today’s news
continues the trend of deteriorating trading conditions TRG has
experienced in recent months. The quantum is clearly worse than we had
expected. We have lowered our PBT estimate for 2016 by 14% from
£90.1 million to £77.7 million, which is based on an assumption of -
3.2% LFLs. Our estimate for 2017 falls by 19% from £96.2 million to
£78.3 million, which assume a further -1.0% LFL decline against a
negative comp in 2016. We expect TRG to continue to pay a dividend,
but reduce our expectations in line with our reduced EPS estimates.
 Departure of CFO. After 11 years with TRG, CFO Stephen Critoph has
left the group and a successor will be appointed in due course.

11:23 am
BE

And, fresh off the conference call, Mark Brumby.

BE

Timing unprecedented, content thin, co skewered on ‘will-you, won’t-you’ re dividend cut

· Little financial info (CFO now ex-plank) & Chairman Jackson not in evidence

· Mr Briethaupt lonely & out there on his own

· Has our sympathy but there’s a money bonfire going on, burning on his watch.

· CFO gone to ‘refresh the Board’. Rubbish, where’s the new one?

· This was as bad a conference call as we have heard in many, many years.

BE

Where to from here?
· Sales momentum awful. Co expects FY LfL sales down between 2.5% and 5.0%.

· Years of price gouging (a.k.a. ‘top quartile pricing’), underinvestment now home to roost

· Shares down 23% today, down nearly 2/3 from peak.

· £880m (yes, nearly £1bn) of somebody’s money has gone to heaven

· Estimates cut to c£76m (c30p EPS) & dividend uncertain.

11:24 am
PM

Actually, you can debate this all you like from a strategic poiint of views, but when a restaurant business puts images like this on its Instagram you're counting the days...

PM

PM

I mean, jeez

TheLeggie -- maple syrup maybe, pancakes underneath

Thing is, Danny Breithaupt has a decent reputation even in the trade, where everyone hates everyone. But the problems with this thing now feels like they're snowballing.

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 530.00, down 21 (-3.81%), High: 536.00, Low: 523.50, Volume: 13.13m
BE

It's the exit rate into Q2 that's the big concern

PM

??

11:28 am
BE

Airlines are acronym soup, so apologies, I'm just going to cut and paste some Barclays in here.

BE

Q1 EBIT was €155m, inline with our forecasts (€158m) and slightly ahead of consensus (€145m).

· Unit revenue was worse than we had expected (-5.2% ex-FX/Aer Lingus vs our -4%), while ex-fuel CASK was slightly down (-0.5% ex-FX/Aer Lingus vs our -1.5%). Yields tracked inline with Q4 (-3% to -4%) through January/February, but there was a sharp impact from the Brussels attacks and Easter timing (lack of corporate demand) in the last week of March.

· By region, Europe and Domestic were fairly resilient (Europe RASK ex-FX -4.6% on capacity growth of +11.7%, Domestic -5.6% on capacity growth of 9.7%). North America and Asia Pacific were clearly the weak spots.

· The March effects are continuing into Q2, with inbound longhaul non-premium being the key impacted area, along with some continued softness in corporate trends. In response, IAG is making some short term capacity adjustments (full year proforma capacity is now +4.9% vs prior +5.3%).

· Ex-fuel CASK guidance has been updated to -1% for the full year (given the tough comparable, ex-fuel CASK may be positive in Q2, but then better in the second half).

· Full year EBIT guidance has been maintained (implied €3.2bn in 2016), although there is clearly less upside than previous.

BE

Or if you want it for people who speak English, the guidance goes ..........

11:29 am
BE

January and February’s revenue was in line with Q4 2015 trends. March revenue was affected by the timing of Easter and the Brussels terrorist attacks with the latter continuing into quarter
two.

BE

Revenue trends in quarter two have been affected by the aftermath
of the Brussels terrorist attacks, as well as some softness in underlying premium demand.
As a result, IAG has moderated its short term capacity growth plans

BE

That's a surprise, the capacity line.

11:30 am
BE

And is probably good news for peers, even though there's a lot of moving parts required to assume that.

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 13.33, down 0.16 (-1.19%), High: 13.40, Low: 13.13, Volume: 568.49k
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,488, down 27 (-1.78%), High: 1,500, Low: 1,477, Volume: 482.96k
11:31 am
BE

Here's SocGen.

BE

IAG tends to over-deliver on expectations, so
we think the consensus beat at the op. results level (€155m reported vs €145m cons) may
not be enough to compensate for the cautious trading comments. Underlying pressure on
unit revenues was also relatively high. All in all we tend to expect a negative initial reaction
this morning.

BE

Our valuation is based on a target 2016e
adjusted EV/EBITDAR multiple of 6x, in line with IAG's trading valuation over the past two
years and implying a 20% premium to the peer group (European flag carriers). We apply a
premium to capture IAG’s superior market position (London and transatlantic). We adjust
EV for capitalised aircraft leases by adding 8x the annual lease charge.

11:32 am
BE

And Deutsche.

BE

Q1 Revenue trends Capacity Fuel Bill
At its FY results on 26th February IAG said that revenue trends in Q1 appeared similar to those experienced in Q4 (cons FX RASK pre-Aer Lingus of -3.7%). As reported today, lfl RASK has come in at -5.2% with the difference being that March yields were impacted by Brussels and the timing of Easter.
Flown ASK capacity in Q1 increased by 11.9%, reasonably consistent with the previously planned 12.2%. Looking ahead though, it is clear that the previously planned growth of 13.7%/10.5%/6.0% growth in Q2/Q3/Q4 will be cut back. We will only know by how much however when IAG’s Q1 presentation is out at 0800 UKT.
Similarly we do not yet have IAG’s latest fuel bill estimate for the year which will also be in the presentation. The previous estimate in February was for a fuel bill of EUR4.8bn using $360/mt and FX of 1.10$/EUR. We forecast a 2016 fuel bill of EUR5.0bn and it may be the case that IAG’s fuel bill estimate is revised higher given that spot jet fuel is c$441/mt.
Overall
We believe IAG is trading extremely cheaply despite demonstrating highly rational capacity behavior and unwavering cost focus. It seems the issues at the moment are Brexit risks and whether marginal buyers can accept “late cycle” risk. Fundamentally however we believe IAG is clearly a BUY.

PM

Welcome to ML

11:33 am
BE

You can rate IAG like a traditional airline, cyclically exposed and likely to go bust ever decade or so.

PM

Like clockwork

BE

Or you can rate it like a bigger more flexible company that can cut costs and capacity to defend earnings in cyclical downturns, so probably won't go bust.

11:34 am
BE

A forward PE of, what, 6? suggests the market's still doing the former.

BE

That's understandable, but I'm not sure it's sensible.

PM

hmm

11:35 am
undefined
BE

(Though I do also recognise that pilots are difficult to sack and old planes are hard to sell.)

BE

Ophir requested several times.

11:35 am
PM

Go on then

BE

Not the best-timed upgrade from Merrill Lynch yesterday, I note in passing.

BE

Went to buy from underperform, saying Schlumberger's backing of the Fortuna project was a huge reassurance.

11:37 am
BE

And as of today, Schlumberger is no longer backing the Fortuna project.

Ophir Energy PLC (OPHR:LSE): Last: 76.50, down 15.4 (-16.76%), High: 78.00, Low: 69.90, Volume: 10.42m
PM

It's quite a reaction

11:38 am
BE

It is, and clearly it's on the worry that the FLNG project in Equatorial Guinea isn't all that.

BE

Given guidance is otherwise reiterated.

PM

Fortuna -- they can't fund it

11:39 am
BE

VSA, quickly ...........

BE

However, OPHR still believes the project is financially attractive and remains in discussions with other parties over the funding of the project. After completion of the FEED studies OPHR estimates the capex requirement from FID to first gas has now come down from US$600m to US$450-500m gross.

The result of this means it is likely that the timings on the project will now be pushed back several months and FID is now anticipated in Q4 2016 with first gas in early 2020.

BE

And Jefferies, not so quickly.

11:39 am
BE

Ophir - Schlumberger discussions terminated over Fortuna FLNG. Since the 26 January 2016 announcement of a non-binding Heads of Terms Agreement with Schlumberger for upstream participation, Schlumberger has satisfactorily completed its technical due diligence. However, Ophir and Schlumberger have been unable to complete the transaction on the terms agreed in the Heads of Terms. As such, discussions between the parties have terminated.

Other parties suggested and upstream capex take a further cut. Ophir has remained in active discussions with a number of other parties with regard to participation in and funding of the Fortuna FLNG Project. These discussions include upstream equity participation, vendor financing and pre-sales of gas. In addition, after completion of the upstream FEED studies, and EPCIC bids having been received as planned earlier this month, the forward upstream capex requirement from FID to first gas has been further reduced from $600mm (gross) to $450-500mm (gross). Offtake selection has progressed to a decision between three alternative solutions. Fully-termed LNG sales agreements are nearing completion.

Ophir still expects to make FID in 4Q16 with first gas forecast for early 2020.

“We continue to work closely with Golar, the prospective offtakers and the other potential partners and remain confident that we will take the FID in 2016".

BE

What NAV now? The value argument for OPHR starts with $614m of cash at FY15 for 56p/sh. Including working capital and $260m of drawn debt, reduces net cash to US$257m or 24p/sh. This we include in our 54p Core NAV for Ophir (US$592m) along with ex Salamander production assets (10,500 - 11,500boe/d guidance for 2016). The 54mmboe of 2P reserves show the company trading at US$12.8/boe.

Upside above 54p Core is from Ophir's remaining 20% stake in Offshore Tanzania LNG (now with Shell as 60% Operator) and 80% stake in the "Fortuna FLNG" project offshore Equatorial Guinea. These two positions contain (FY15 results): "996mmboe of contingent resource. We expect a significant proportion of the contingent resource to move to reserves when we make the FID on the Fortuna FLNG project" Including these 2C resources (gas) shows the company trading at US$0.7/boe 2P+2C.

Our 97p Price Target for Ophir includes 43p or US$475m of risked value for both Tanzania (11p) and Fortuna FLNG (33p). The irony of this valuation is that OPHR has already monetised half its stake in Tanzania for US$1bn post tax proceeds in late 2013. But that was then and this now, the market has been willing to price in only a fraction of that sale price in recent times (and industry has not stepped in to take advantage of any perceived value arbitrage). $475m or 43p for these two LNG positions hardly seems like a stretched valuation but without tangible progress through FID (at either project) any on paper valuation remains just that, on paper. As for market reaction to this news, ironically OPHR has rallied hard in April from levels approaching year lows at ~75p. The stock could test those lows on this news and still factor in some value for LNG assets. With no balance sheet issues, however, it would seem an over-reaction for further downside toward Core NAV.

BE

(@TheLeggie: they haven't sent me it, for some reason.)

11:41 am
BE

For the bear case on Ophir, by the way, spin back to Stifel's coverage.

BE

Which questions whether their GoFLNG tech is smoke and mirrors.

BE

This is the extraction tech that means Ophir can hit a gas extraction cost much lower than the industry average.

11:43 am
BE

Here's a bit of an old Stifel note.

BE

While this technology has not been implemented
before, there is nothing new in it, and it is just a matter of fitting already known
components into a space constrained vessel. The involvement of high quality
partners in all parts of the value chain, combined with the significant number of
interested offtakers, puts a stamp of approval on the project as a whole.

BE

This technology has never been implemented
before, and there is no evidence that it would work, especially not at such a big
cost advantage over the majority of other LNG projects in the world. In terms
of the offtake, the terms are still unclear. In fact, it appears that the offtake
agreement is headed in a direction where the agreed price would be in part
linked to the UK spot natural gas price. Therefore, one can argue that having a
‘long-term’ gas sales contract to sell gas at spot price is not necessarily a
strong stamp of approval.

11:43 am
PM

I sense a 'but' coming

BE

Given the amount of time and resources
that the company has put into this project, it would be unreasonable for us to
question its validity solely based on market skepticism. Therefore, for the time
being, we have implemented a majority of management guided parameters
(production, capex, opex, etc) into our model. However, given the uncertainty
around it, we also expect investors to require higher than normal returns for it.
Therefore, we have decided to value the project using a 15% discount rate,
compared to our typical non-OECD discount rate of 12%. We are also using
long-term UK natural gas pricing of $6.5/mcf (linked to our $US65 long-term
Brent oil price) for the full duration of the project. This has resulted in only
marginal increase in valuation of 82p/share (Figure 1). Therefore, we remain
sellers until we see a better entry point.

BE

That's from last year, but I include it as an example of why Ophir needs credibility.

11:44 am
BE

And having Schlumberger walk isn't going to help on that score.

Therefore until we have further clarity on GKP’s near term capital position, we place our TP and recommendation Under Review (from BUY and 48p TP).

11:54 am
BE

Kenmare has today announced a significant financial restructuring and deleveraging plan to materially reduce the company's net debt from US$368M at the end of 2015 to no more than US$100M. The proposed refinancing package consists of a number of elements, many of which are still subject to final agreement with a number of parties, including the group's lenders.

Cornerstone placing: The State General Reserve Fund, a sovereign wealth fund of the Sultanate of Oman, and King Ally Holdings, a Chinese chemicals trading company, will each subscribe for US$100M of new shares.

Firm placing: A number of new and existing institutional investors will participate in a firm placing of shares, at a similar price to the cornerstone investors, raising an additional US$75M.

Debt reduction: US$200M of the proceeds of the Cornerstone Placing and Firm Placing will be used to repay US$250M of debt together with an amount equal to interest accruing on project loans from 25 November 2015 to receipt of lender approvals. The balance of the net proceeds will be retained by Kenmare for working capital.

Open offer: An open offer will be made to existing shareholders on the same terms as the cornerstone investors and in the firm placing. The maximum size of the open offer will be sufficient to enable the total outstanding indebtedness to be discharged on a 3:4 basis. In other words, for example, if US$75M of equity can be raised in the open offer, debt will be reduced by US$100M. If the open offer fails to reduce outstanding debt to US$100M, the excess will be equitised at the issue price.

Share capital reorganisation: After the various equity raisings, the company will consolidate its ordinary shares. The two cornerstone investors will hold no more than 29.9% of the equity, while the equity positions of the company's lenders will depend, in part, on the success of the open offer.

Our view

This restructuring will allow Kenmare to significantly strengthen its balance sheet. It will substantially reduce the company's net debt position, significantly reduce financing costs and provide working capital for the group. With a modest resulting net debt position, the company will be well placed to benefit from the embryonic signs of recovery in the titanium dioxide feedstock and pigment markets. Pigment demand correlates well with global GDP and the company should benefit as the global economy gradually recovers.

BE

And Shore.

BE

In short, it seems clear to us that there will be significant dilution of existing shareholders. Additionally, Kenmare reiterated its cautions that its lenders have not yet actually approved the deleveraging plan, that shareholder approval of a number of resolutions will be required, and that the uncertainties have resulted in the inclusion of an ‘emphasis of matter’ in the company’s accounts for 2015.

Unhelpfully, Q1 2016 production results were not particularly strong. Excavated ore tonnage was ever so slightly above Q4 2015, but significantly lower grade meant that ilmenite, zircon and rutile production were 3%, 20% and 35% down, respectively. Shipments were also down 33%, due to the delayed arrival of a vessel and bad weather delaying the departure of two large ilmenite shipments.

Fortunately, on the market front, Kenmare reported that its analysis shows that the market for merchant sulphate ilmenite is in “global supply deficit”, with inventories appearing to be declining. According to the company, this is “evidenced by the price increases” being seen in the Chinese ilmenite spot market over recent months.

For the full-year 2016, Kenmare is guiding for production of 950kt ilmenite, 70kt zircon and 8kt rutile at cash operating costs of US$141/t. Average head grades over 2016-2020 are expected to be c.4.5% (2011-2015: c.5.2%). Sustaining capex is expected to average c.US$20m in the medium term. Capex required to enhance the mining fleet over 2016-2020 is projected at US$100m, but the company hastened to add that this has yet to be approved and no material expenditure is expected before Q4 2017.
